div1.stage: SCENE: A wild and desolate region; only thickets, rocks, and a single tree are seen. Euelpides and Pisthetaerus enter, each with a bird in his hand.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: To his jay. Do you think I should walk straight for yon tree?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: To his crow. Cursed beast, what are you croaking to me? . . . to retrace my steps?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Why, you wretch, we are wandering at random, we are exerting ourselves only to return to the same spot; we're wasting our time.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: To think that I should trust to this crow, which has made me cover more than a thousand furlongs!

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: And that I, in obedience to this jay, should have worn my toes down to the nails!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: If only I knew where we were . . .

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Could you find your country again from here?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: No, I feel quite sure I could not, any more than could Execestides find his.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Alas!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Aye, aye, my friend, it's surely the road of “alases” we are following.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: That Philocrates, the bird-seller, played us a scurvy trick, when he pretended these two guides could help us to find Tereus, the Epops, who is a bird, without being born of one. He has indeed sold us this jay, a true son of Tharrhelides, for an obolus, and this crow for three, but what can they do? Why, nothing whatever but bite and scratch! To his jay. What's the matter with you then, that you keep opening your beak? Do you want us to fling ourselves headlong down these rocks? There is no road that way.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Not even the vestige of a trail in any direction

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: And what does the crow say about the road to follow?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: By Zeus, it no longer croaks the same thing it did.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: And which way does it tell us to go now?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: It says that, by dint of gnawing, it will devour my fingers.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: What misfortune is ours! we strain every nerve to get to the crows, do everything we can to that end, and we cannot find our way! Yes, spectators, our madness is quite different from that of Sacas. He is not a citizen, and would fain be one at any cost; we, on the contrary, born of an honorable tribe and family and living in the midst of our fellow-citizens, we have fled from our country as hard as ever we could go. It's not that we hate it; we recognize it to be great and rich, likewise that everyone has the right to ruin himself paying taxes; but the crickets only chirrup among the fig-trees for a month or two, whereas the Athenians spend their whole lives in chanting forth judgments from their law-courts. That is why we started off with a basket, a stew-pot and some myrtle boughs and have come to seek a quiet country in which to settle. We are going to Tereus, the Epops, to learn from him, whether, in his aerial flights, he has noticed some town of this kind.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Here! look!

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Why, the crow has been directing me to something up there for some time now.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: And the jay is also opening it beak and craning its neck to show me I know not what. Clearly, there are some birds about here. We shall soon know, if we kick up a noise to start them.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Do you know what to do? Knock your leg against this rock.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: And you your head to double the noise.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Well then use a stone instead; take one and hammer with it.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Good idea! He does so. Ho there, within! Slave! slave!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What's that, friend! You say, “slave,” to summon Epops? It would be much better to shout, “Epops, Epops!”

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Well then, Epops! Must I knock again? Epops!

sp.speaker: Trochilus
sp.p: Rushing out of a thicket. Who's there? Who calls my master?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: In terror. Apollo the Deliverer! what an enormous beak!

div1.stage: He defecates. In the confusion both the jay and the crow fly away.

sp.speaker: Trochilus
sp.p: Equally frightened. Good god! they are bird-catchers.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Reassuring himself. But is it so terrible? Wouldn't it be better to explain things?

sp.speaker: Trochilus
sp.p: Also reassuring himself. You're done for.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: But we are not men.

sp.speaker: Trochilus
sp.p: What are you, then?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Defecating also. I am the Fearling, an African bird.

sp.speaker: Trochilus
sp.p: You talk nonsense.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Well, then, just ask it of my feet.

sp.speaker: Trochilus
sp.p: And this other one, what bird is it? To Pisthetaerus. Speak up!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Weakly. I? I am a Crapple, from the land of the pheasants.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: But you yourself, in the name of the gods! what animal are you?

sp.speaker: Trochilus
sp.p: Why, I am a slave-bird.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Why, have you been conquered by a cock?

sp.speaker: Trochilus
sp.p: No, but when my master was turned into a hoopoe, he begged me to become a bird also, to follow and to serve him.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Does a bird need a servant, then?

sp.speaker: Trochilus
sp.p: That's no doubt because he was once a man. At times he wants to eat a dish of sardines from Phalerum; I seize my dish and fly to fetch him some. Again he wants some pea-soup; I seize a ladle and a pot and run to get it.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: This is, then, truly a running-bird. Come, Trochilus, do us the kindness to call your master.

sp.speaker: Trochilus
sp.p: Why, he has just fallen asleep after a feed of myrtle-berries and a few grubs.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Never mind; wake him up.

sp.speaker: Trochilus
sp.p: I am certain he will be angry. However, I will wake him to please you.

div1.stage: He goes back into the thicket.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: As soon as Trochilus is out of sight. You cursed brute! why, I am almost dead with terror!

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Oh! my god! it was sheer fear that made me lose my jay.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Ah! you big coward! were you so frightened that you let go your jay?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: And did you not lose your crow, when you fell sprawling on the ground? Tell me that.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Where is it, then?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: It flew away.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: And you did not let it go? Oh! you brave fellow!

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: From within. Open the thicket, that I may go out!

div1.stage: He comes out of the thicket.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: By Heracles! what a creature! what plumage! What means this triple crest?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Who wants me?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Banteringly. The twelve great gods have used you ill, it seems.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Are you twitting me about my feathers? I have been a man, strangers.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: It's not you we are jeering at.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: At what, then?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Why, it's your beak that looks so ridiculous to us.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: This is how Sophocles outrages me in his tragedies. Know, I once was Tereus.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: You were Tereus, and what are you now? a bird or a peacock?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: I am a bird.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Then where are your feathers? I don't see any.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: They have fallen off.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Through illness?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: No. All birds moult their feathers, you know, every winter, and others grow in their place. But tell me, who are you?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: We? We are mortals.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: From what country?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: From the land of the beautiful galleys.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Are you dicasts?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: No, if anything, we are anti-dicasts.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Is that kind of seed sown among you?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: You have to look hard to find even a little in our fields.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: What brings you here?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: We wish to pay you a visit.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: What for?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Because you formerly were a man, like we are, formerly you had debts, as we have, formerly you did not want to pay them, like ourselves; furthermore, being turned into a bird, you have when flying seen all lands and seas. Thus you have all human knowledge as well as that of birds. And hence we have come to you to beg you to direct us to some cosy town, in which one can repose as if on thick coverlets.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: And are you looking for a greater city than Athens?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: No, not a greater, but one more pleasant to live in.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Then you are looking for an aristocratic country.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: I? Not at all! I hold the son of Scellias in horror.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: But, after all, what sort of city would please you best?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: A place where the following would be the most important business transacted. —Some friend would come knocking at the door quite early in the morning saying, “By Olympian Zeus, be at my house early, as soon as you have bathed, and bring your children too. I am giving a nuptial feast, so don't fail, or else don't cross my threshold when I am in distress.”

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Ah! that's what may be called being fond of hardships! To Pisthetaerus. And what say you?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: My tastes are similar.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: And they are?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: I want a town where the father of a handsome lad will stop in the street and say to me reproachfully as if I had failed him, “Ah! Is this well done, Stilbonides? You met my son coming from the bath after the gymnasium and you neither spoke to him, nor kissed him, nor took him with you, nor ever once felt his balls. Would anyone call you an old friend of mine?”

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Ah! wag, I see you are fond of suffering. But there is a city of delights such as you want. It's on the Red Sea.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Oh, no. Not a sea-port, where some fine morning the Salaminian galley can appear, bringing a process-server along. Have you no Greek town you can propose to us?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Why not choose Lepreum in Elis for your settlement?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: By Zeus! I could not look at Lepreum without disgust, because of Melanthius.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Then, again, there is the Opuntian Locris, where you could live.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: I would not be Opuntian for a talent. But come, what is it like to live with the birds? You should know pretty well.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Why, it's not a disagreeable life. In the first place, one has no purse.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: That does away with a lot of roguery.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: For food the gardens yield us white sesame, myrtle-berries, poppies and mint.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Why, 'tis the life of the newly-wed indeed.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Ha! I am beginning to see a great plan, which will transfer the supreme power to the birds, if you will but take my advice.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Take your advice? In what way?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: In what way? Well, firstly, do not fly in all directions with open beak; it is not dignified. Among us, when we see a thoughtless man, we ask, “What sort of bird is this?” and Teleas answers, “It's a man who has no brain, a bird that has lost his head, a creature you cannot catch, for it never remains in any one place.”

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: By Zeus himself! your jest hits the mark. What then is to be done?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Found a city.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: We birds? But what sort of city should we build?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Oh, really, really! you talk like such a fool! Look down.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: I am looking.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Now look up.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: I am looking.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Turn your head round.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Ah! it will be pleasant for me if I end in twisting my neck off!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What have you seen?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: The clouds and the sky.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Very well! is not this the pole of the birds then?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: How their pole?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Or, if you like it, their place. And since it turns and passes through the whole universe, it is called ‘pole.’ If you build and fortify it, you will turn your pole into a city. In this way you will reign over mankind as you do over the grasshoppers and you will cause the gods to die of rabid hunger.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: The air is between earth and heaven. When we want to go to Delphi, we ask the Boeotians for leave of passage; in the same way, when men sacrifice to the gods, unless the latter pay you tribute, you exercise the right of every nation towards strangers and don't allow the smoke of the sacrifices to pass through your city and territory.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: By earth! by snares! by network! by cages! I never heard of anything more cleverly conceived; and, if the other birds approve, I am going to build the city along with you.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Who will explain the matter to them?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: You must yourself. Before I came they were quite ignorant, but since I have lived with them I have taught them to speak.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: But how can they be gathered together?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Easily. I will hasten down to the thicket to waken my dear Procne and as soon as they hear our voices, they will come to us hot wing.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: My dear bird, lose no time, please! Fly at once into the thicket and awaken Procne.

div1.stage: Epops rushes into the thicket.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Chase off drowsy sleep, dear companion. Let the sacred hymn gush from thy divine throat in melodious strains; roll forth in soft cadence your refreshing melodies to bewail the fate of Itys, which has been the cause of so many tears to us both. Your pure notes rise through the thick leaves of the yew-tree right up to the throne of Zeus, where Phoebus listens to you, Phoebus with his golden hair. And his ivory lyre responds to your plaintive accents; he gathers the choir of the gods and from their immortal lips pours forth a sacred chant of blessed voices.

sp.stage: The flute is played behind the scene, imitating the song of the nightingale.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Oh! by Zeus! what a throat that little bird possesses. He has filled the whole thicket with honey-sweet melody!

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Hush!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Be still!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What for?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Epops is going to sing again.

sp.speaker: Epops
Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Can you see any bird?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: By Phoebus, no! and yet I am straining my eyesight to scan the sky.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: It was hardly worth Epops' while to go and bury himself in the thicket like a hatching plover.

sp.speaker: A Bird
sp.p: Torotix, torotix.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Wait, friend, there's a bird.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: By Zeus, it is a bird, but what kind? Isn't it a peacock?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.stage: As Epops comes out of the thicket.
sp.p: Epops will tell us. What is this bird?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: It's not one of those you are used to seeing; it's a bird from the marshes.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Oh! oh! but he is very handsome with his wings as crimson as flame.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Undoubtedly; indeed he is called flamingo.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Hi! I say! You!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What are you shouting for?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Why, here's another bird.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Aye, indeed; this one's a foreign bird too. To Epops. What is this bird from beyond the mountains with a look as solemn as it is stupid?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: He is called the Mede.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: The Mede! But, by Heracles, how, if a Mede, has he flown here without a camel?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Here's another bird with a crest.

div1.stage: From here on, the numerous birds that make up the Chorus keep rushing in.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Ah! that's curious. I say, Epops,you are not the only one of your kind then?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: This bird is the son of Philocles, who is the son of Epops; so that, you see, I am his grandfather; just as one might say, Hipponicus, the son of Callias, who is the son of Hipponicus.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Then this bird is Callias! Why, what a lot of his feathers he has lost!

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: That's because he is honest; so the informers set upon him and the women too pluck out his feathers.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: By Poseidon, do you see that many-coloured bird? What is his name?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: This one? That's the glutton.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Is there another glutton besides Cleonymus? But why, if he is Cleonymus, has he not thrown away his crest? But what is the meaning of all these crests? Have these birds come to contend for the double stadium prize?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: They are like the Carians, who cling to the crests of their mountains for greater safety.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Oh, Poseidon! look what awful swarms of birds are gathering here!

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: By Phoebus! what a cloud! The entrance to the stage is no longer visible so closely do they fly together.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Here is the partridge.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Why, there is the francolin.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: There is the poachard.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Here is the kingfisher. To Epops. What's that bird behind the kingfisher?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: That's the barber.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: What? a bird a barber?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Why, Sporgilus is one.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Here comes the owl.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: And who is it brings an owl to Athens?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Here is the magpie, the turtle-dove, the swallow, the horned-owl, the buzzard, the pigeon, the falcon, the ring-dove, the cuckoo, the red-foot, the red-cap, the purple-cap, the kestrel, the diver, the ousel, the osprey, the woodpecker . . .

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Oh! what a lot of birds! Oh! what a lot of blackbirds! How they scold, how they come rushing up! What a noise! what a noise! Can they be bearing us ill-will? Oh! there! there! they are opening their beaks and staring at us.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Why, so they are.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Popopopopopo. Where is he who called me? Where am I to find him?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: I have been waiting for you a long while! I never fail in my word to my friends.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Tititititititi. What good news have you for me?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Something that concerns our common safety, and that is just as pleasant as it is to the point. Two men, who are subtle reasoners, have come here to seek me.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Where? How? What are you saying?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: I say, two old men have come from the abode of humans to propose a vast and splendid scheme to us.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Oh! it's a horrible, unheard-of crime! What are you saying?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Never let my words scare you.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: What have you done to me?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: I have welcomed two men, who wish to live with us.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: And you have dared to do that!

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Yes, and I am delighted at having done so.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: And are they already with us?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Just as much as I am.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Ah! ah! we are betrayed; 'tis sacrilege! Our friend, he who picked up corn-seeds in the same plains as ourselves, has violated our ancient laws; he has broken the oaths that bind all birds; he has laid a snare for me, he has handed us over to the attacks of that impious race which, throughout all time, has never ceased to war against us.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: As for this traitorous bird, we will decide his case later, but the two old men shall be punished forthwith; we are going to tear them to pieces.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: It's all over with us.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: You are the sole cause of all our trouble. Why did you bring me from down yonder?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: To have you with me.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Say rather to have me melt into tears.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Go on! you are talking nonsense. How will you weep with your eyes pecked out?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Io! io! forward to the attack, throw yourselves upon the foe, spill his blood; take to your wings and surround them on all sides. Woe to them! let us get to work with our beaks, let us devour them. Nothing can save them from our wrath, neither the mountain forests, nor the clouds that float in the sky, nor the foaming deep.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Come, peck, tear to ribbons. Where is the chief of the cohort? Let him engage the right wing.

div1.stage: They rush at the two Athenians.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: This is the fatal moment. Where shall I fly to, unfortunate wretch that I am?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Wait! Stay here!

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: That they may tear me to pieces?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: And how do you think to escape them?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: I don't know at all.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Come, I will tell you. We must stop and fight them. Let us arm ourselves with these stew-pots.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Why with the stew-pots?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: The owl will not attack us then.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: But do you see all those hooked claws?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Take the spit and pierce the foe on your side.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: And how about my eyes?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Protect them with this dish or this vinegar-pot.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Oh! what cleverness! what inventive genius! You are a great general, even greater than Nicias, where stratagem is concerned.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Forward, forward, charge with your beaks! Come, no delay. Tear, pluck, strike, flay them, and first of all smash the stew-pot.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.stage: Stepping in front of the Chorus.
sp.p: Oh, most cruel of all animals, why tear these two men to pieces, why kill them? What have they done to you? They belong to the same tribe, to the same family as my wife.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Are wolves to be spared? Are they not our most mortal foes? So let us punish them.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: If they are your foes by nature, they are your friends in heart, and they come here to give you useful advice.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Advice or a useful word from their lips, from them, the enemies of my forebears?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: The wise can often profit by the lessons of a foe, for caution is the mother of safety. It is just such a thing as one will not learn from a friend and which an enemy compels you to know. To begin with, it's the foe and not the friend that taught cities to build high walls, to equip long vessels of war; and it's this knowledge that protects our children, our slaves and our wealth.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Well then, I agree, let us first hear them, for that is best; one can even learn something in an enemy's school.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Their wrath seems to cool. Draw back a little.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: It's only justice, and you will thank me later.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Never have we opposed your advice up to now.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: They are in a more peaceful mood; put down your stew-pot and your two dishes; spit in hand, doing duty for a spear, let us mount guard inside the camp close to the pot and watch in our arsenal closely; for we must not fly.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: You are right. But where shall we be buried, if we die?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: In the Ceramicus; for, to get a public funeral, we shall tell the Strategi that we fell at Orneae, fighting the country's foes.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Return to your ranks and lay down your courage beside your wrath as the hoplites do. Then let us ask these men who they are, whence they come, and with what intent. Here, Epops, answer me.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Are you calling me? What do you want of me?

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Who are they? From what country?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Strangers, who have come from Greece, the land of the wise.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: And what fate has led them hither to the land of the birds?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Their love for you and their wish to share your kind of life; to dwell and remain with you always.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Indeed, and what are their plans?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: They are wonderful, incredible, unheard of.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Why, do they think to see some advantage that determines them to settle here? Are they hoping with our help to triumph over their foes or to be useful to their friends?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: They speak of benefits so great it is impossible either to describe or conceive them; all shall be yours, all that we see here, there, above and below us; this they vouch for.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Are they mad?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: They are the sanest people in the world.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Clever men?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: The slyest of foxes, cleverness its very self, men of the world, cunning, the cream of knowing folk.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Tell them to speak and speak quickly; why, as I listen to you, I am beside myself with delight.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Here, you there, take all these weapons and hang them up inside close to the fire, near the figure of the god who presides there and under his protection; To Pisthetaerus. as for you, address the birds, tell them why I have gathered them together.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Not I, by Apollo, unless they agree with me as the little ape of an armorer agreed with his wife, not to bite me, nor pull me by the balls, nor shove things into my . . .

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.stage: Bending over and pointing his finger at his anus.
sp.p: Do you mean this?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: No, I mean my eyes.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Swear it.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: I swear it and, if I keep my promise, let judges and spectators give me the victory unanimously.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: It is a bargain.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: And if I break my word, may I succeed by one vote only.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Hearken, ye people! Hoplites, pick up your weapons and return to your firesides; do not fail to read the decrees of dismissal we have posted.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Man is a truly cunning creature, but nevertheless explain. Perhaps you are going to show me some good way to extend my power, some way that I have not had the wit to find out and which you have discovered. Speak! 'tis to your own interest as well as to mine, for if you secure me some advantage, I will surely share it with you.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: But what object can have induced you to come among us? Speak boldly, for I shall not break the truce, —until you have told us all.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: I am bursting with desire to speak; I have already mixed the dough of my address and nothing prevents me from kneading it.... Slave! bring the chaplet and water, which you must pour over my hands. Be quick!

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Is it a question of feasting? What does it all mean?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: By Zeus, no! but I am hunting for fine, tasty words to break down the hardness of their hearts. To the Chorus. I grieve so much for you, who at one time were kings...

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: We kings? Over whom?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: ... of all that exists, firstly of me and of this man, even of Zeus himself. Your race is older than Saturn, the Titans and the Earth.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: What, older than the Earth!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: By Phoebus, yes.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: By Zeus, but I never knew that before!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: That's because you are ignorant and heedless, and have never read your Aesop. He is the one who tells us that the lark was born before all other creatures, indeed before the Earth; his father died of sickness, but the Earth did not exist then; he remained unburied for five days, when the bird in its dilemma decided, for want of a better place, to entomb its father in its own head.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: So that the lark's father is buried at Cephalae.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Hence, if they existed before the Earth, before the gods, the kingship belongs to them by right of priority.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Undoubtedly, but sharpen your beak well; Zeus won't be in a hurry to hand over his scepter to the woodpecker.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: It was not the gods, but the birds, who were formerly the masters and kings over men; of this I have a thousand proofs. First of all, I will point you to the cock, who governed the Persians before all other monarchs, before Darius and Megabazus. It's in memory of his reign that he is called the Persian bird.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: For this reason also, even to-day, he alone of all the birds wears his tiara straight on his head, like the Great King.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: He was so strong, so great, so feared, that even now, on account of his ancient power, everyone jumps out of bed as soon as ever he crows at daybreak. Blacksmiths, potters, tanners, shoemakers, bathmen, corn-dealers, lyre-makers and armorers, all put on their shoes and go to work before it is daylight.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: I can tell you something about that. It was the cock's fault that I lost a splendid tunic of Phrygian wool. I was at a feast in town, given to celebrate the birth of a child; I had drunk pretty freely and had just fallen asleep, when a cock, I suppose in a greater hurry than the rest, began to crow. I thought it was dawn and set out for Halimus. I had hardly got beyond the walls, when a footpad struck me in the back with his bludgeon; down I went and wanted to shout, but he had already made off with my mantle.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Formerly also the kite was ruler and king over the Greeks.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: The Greeks?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: And when he was king, he was the one who first taught them to fall on their knees before the kites.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: By Zeus! that's what I did myself one day on seeing a kite; but at the moment I was on my knees, and leaning backwards with mouth agape, I bolted an obolus and was forced to carry my meal-sack home empty.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: The cuckoo was king of Egypt and of the whole of Phoenicia. When he called out “cuckoo,” all the Phoenicians hurried to the fields to reap their wheat and their barley.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Hence no doubt the proverb, “Cuckoo! cuckoo! go to the fields, ye circumcised.”

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: So powerful were the birds that the kings of Grecian cities, Agamemnon, Menelaus, for instance, carried a bird on the tip of their scepters, who had his share of all presents.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: That I didn't know and was much astonished when I saw Priam come upon the stage in the tragedies with a bird, which kept watching Lysicrates to see if he got any present.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: But the strongest proof of all is that Zeus, who now reigns, is represented as standing with an eagle on his head as a symbol of his royalty; his daughter has an owl, and Phoebus, as his servant, has a hawk.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: By Demeter, the point is well taken. But what are all these birds doing in heaven?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: When anyone sacrifices and, according to the rite, offers the entrails to the gods, these birds take their share before Zeus. Formerly men always swore by the birds and never by the gods. And even now Lampon swears by the goose whenever he wishes to deceive someone. Thus it is clear that you were once great and sacred,

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: but now you are looked upon as slaves, as fools, as Maneses; stones are thrown at you as at raving madmen, even in holy places. A crowd of bird-catchers sets snares, traps, limed twigs and nets of all sorts for you; you are caught, you are sold in heaps and the buyers finger you over to be certain you are fat. Again, if they would but serve you up simply roasted; but they rasp cheese into a mixture of oil, vinegar and laserwort, to which another sweet and greasy sauce is added, and the whole is poured scalding hot over your back, for all the world as if you were diseased meat.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Man, your words have made my heart bleed; I have groaned over the treachery of our fathers, who knew not how to transmit to us the high rank they held from their forefathers. But 'tis a benevolent Genius, a happy Fate, that sends you to us; you shall be our deliverer and I place the destiny of my little ones and my own in your hands with every confidence.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: But hasten to tell me what must be done; we should not be worthy to live, if we did not seek to regain our royalty by every possible means.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: First I advise that the birds gather together in one city and that they build a wall of great bricks, like that at Babylon, round the plains of the air and the whole region of space that divides earth from heaven.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Oh, Cebriones! oh, Porphyrion! what a terribly strong place!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Then, when this has been well done and completed, you demand back the empire from Zeus; if he will not agree, if he refuses and does not at once confess himself beaten, you declare a sacred war against him and forbid the gods henceforward to pass through your country with their tools up, as hitherto, for the purpose of laying their Alcmenas, their Alopes, or their Semeles! if they try to pass through,you put rings on their tools so that they can't make love any longer. You send another messenger to mankind, who will proclaim to them that the birds are kings, that for the future they must first of all sacrifice to them, and only afterwards to the gods; that it is fitting to appoint to each deity the bird that has most in common with it. For instance, are they sacrificing to Aphrodite, let them at the same time offer barley to the coot; are they immolating a sheep to Poseidon, let them consecrate wheat in honor of the duck; if a steer is being offered to Heracles, let honey-cakes be dedicated to the gull; if a goat is being slain for King Zeus, there is a King-Bird, the wren, to whom the sacrifice of a male gnat is due before Zeus himself even.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: This notion of an immolated gnat delights me! And now let the great Zeus thunder!

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: But how will mankind recognize us as gods and not as jays? Us, who have wings and fly?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: You talk rubbish! Hermes is a god and has wings and flies, and so do many other gods. First of all, Victory flies with golden wings, Eros is undoubtedly winged too, and Iris is compared by Homer to a timorous dove.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: But will not Zeus thunder and send his winged bolts against us?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: If men in their blindness do not recognize us as gods and so continue to worship the dwellers in Olympus? Then a cloud of sparrows greedy for corn must descend upon their fields and eat up all their seeds; we shall see then if Demeter will mete them out any wheat.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: By Zeus, she'll take good care she does not, and you will see her inventing a thousand excuses.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: The crows too will prove your divinity to them by pecking out the eyes of their flocks and of their draught-oxen; and then let Apollo cure them, since he is a physician and is paid for the purpose.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Oh! don't do that! Wait first until I have sold my two young bullocks.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: If on the other hand they recognize that you are God, the principle of life, that you are Earth, Kronos, Poseidon, they shall be loaded with benefits.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Name me one of these then.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Firstly, the locusts shall not eat up their vine-blossoms; a legion of owls and kestrels will devour them. Moreover, the gnats and the gallbugs shall no longer ravage the figs; a flock of thrushes shall swallow the whole host down to the very last.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: And how shall we give wealth to mankind? This is their strongest passion.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: When they consult the omens, you will point them to the richest mines, you will reveal the paying ventures to the diviner, and not another shipwreck will happen or sailor perish.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: No more shall perish? How is that?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: When the auguries are examined before starting on a voyage, some bird will not fail to say, “Don't start! there will be a storm,” or else, “Go! you will make a most profitable venture.”

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: I shall buy a trading-vessel and go to sea. I will not stay with you.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: You will discover treasures to them, which were buried in former times, for you know them. Do not all men say, “None knows where my treasure lies, unless perchance it be some bird.”

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: I shall sell my boat and buy a spade to unearth the vessels.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: And how are we to give them health, which belongs to the gods?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: If they are happy, is not that the chief thing towards health? The miserable man is never well.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Old Age also dwells in Olympus. How will they get at it? Must they die in early youth?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Why, the birds, by Zeus, will add three hundred years to their life.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: From whom will they take them?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: From whom? Why, from themselves. Don't you know the cawing crow lives five times as long as a man?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Ah! ah! these are far better kings for us than Zeus!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Far better, are they not? And firstly, we shall not have to build them temples of hewn stone, closed with gates of gold; they will dwell amongst the bushes and in the thickets of green oak; the most venerated of birds will have no other temple than the foliage of the olive tree; we shall not go to Delphi or to Ammon to sacrifice; but standing erect in the midst of arbutus and wild olives and holding forth our hands filled with wheat and barley, we shall pray them to admit us to a share of the blessings they enjoy and shall at once obtain them for a few grains of wheat.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Old man, whom I detested, you are now to me the dearest of all; never shall I, if I can help it, fail to follow your advice.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Inspirited by your words, I threaten my rivals the gods, and I swear that if you march in alliance with me against the gods and are faithful to our just, loyal and sacred bond, we shall soon have shattered their scepter.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: We shall charge ourselves with the performance of everything that requires force; that which demands thought and deliberation shall be yours to supply.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: By Zeus! it's no longer the time to delay and loiter like Nicias; let us act as promptly as possible.... In the first place, come, enter my nest built of brushwood and blades of straw, and tell me your names.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: That is soon done; my name is Pisthetaerus, and his, Euelpides, of the deme Crioa.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Good! and good luck to you.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: We accept the omen.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Come in here.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Very well, you are the one who must lead us and introduce us.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Come then.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.stage: Pisthetaerus starts to fly away, then stops himself.
sp.p: Oh! my god! do come back here. Hi! tell us how we are to follow you. You can fly, but we cannot.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Well, well.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Remember Aesop's fables. It is told there that the fox fared very badly, because he had made an alliance with the eagle.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Be at ease. You shall eat a certain root and wings will grow on your shoulders.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Then let us enter. Xanthias and Manodorus, pick up our baggage.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Hi! Epops! do you hear me?

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Take them off to dine well and call your mate, the melodious Procne, whose songs are worthy of the Muses; she will delight our leisure moments.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Oh! I conjure you, accede to their wish; for this delightful bird will leave her rushes at the sound of your voice; for the sake of the gods, let her come here, so that we may contemplate the nightingale.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Let it be as you desire. Come forth, Procne, show yourself to these strangers.

div1.stage: Procne appears; she resembles a young flute-girl.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Oh! great Zeus! what a beautiful little bird! what a dainty form! what brilliant plumage! Do you know how dearly I should like to get between her thighs?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: She is dazzling all over with gold, like a young girl. Oh! how I should like to kiss her!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Why, wretched man, she has two little sharp points on her beak!

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: I would treat her like an egg, the shell of which we remove before eating it; I would take off her mask and then kiss her pretty face.

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Let us go in.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Lead the way, and may success attend us.Epops goes into the thicket, followed by Pisthetaerus and Euelpides.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Lovable golden bird, whom I cherish above all others, you, whom I associate with all my songs, nightingale, you have come, you have come, to show yourself to me and to charm me with your notes. Come, you, who play spring melodies upon the harmonious flute, lead off our anapests.

div1.stage: The Chorus turns and faces the audience.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Weak mortals, chained to the earth, creatures of clay as frail as the foliage of the woods, you unfortunate race, whose life is but darkness, as unreal as a shadow, the illusion of a dream, hearken to us, who are immortal beings, ethereal, ever young and occupied with eternal thoughts, for we shall teach you about all celestial matters; you shall know thoroughly what is the nature of the birds, what the origin of the gods, of the rivers, of Erebus, and Chaos; thanks to us, even Prodicus will envy you your knowledge.

At the beginning there was only Chaos, Night, dark Erebus, and deep Tartarus. Earth, the air and heaven had no existence. Firstly, blackwinged Night laid a germless egg in the bosom of the infinite deeps of Erebus, and from this, after the revolution of long ages, sprang the graceful Eros with his glittering golden wings, swift as the whirlwinds of the tempest. He mated in deep Tartarus with dark Chaos, winged like himself, and thus hatched forth our race, which was the first to see the light.That of the Immortals did not exist until Eros had brought together all the ingredients of the world, and from their marriage Heaven, Ocean, Earth and the imperishable race of blessed gods sprang into being. Thus our origin is very much older than that of the dwellers in Olympus. We are the offspring of Eros; there are a thousand proofs to show it. We have wings and we lend assistance to lovers. How many handsome youths, who had sworn to remain insensible, have opened their thighs because of our power and have yielded themselves to their lovers when almost at the end of their youth, being led away by the gift of a quail, a waterfowl, a goose, or a cock.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: And what important services do not the birds render to mortals! First of all, they mark the seasons for them, springtime, winter, and autumn.Does the screaming crane migrate to Libya, —it warns the husbandman to sow, the pilot to take his ease beside his tiller hung up in his dwelling, and Orestes to weave a tunic, so that the rigorous cold may not drive him any more to strip other folk. When the kite reappears, he tells of the return of spring and of the period when the fleece of the sheep must be clipped. Is the swallow in sight? All hasten to sell their warm tunic and to buy some light clothing. We are your Ammon, Delphi, Dodona, your Phoebus Apollo. Before undertaking anything, whether a business transaction, a marriage, or the purchase of food, you consult the birds by reading the omens, and you give this name of omen to all signs that tell of the future.With you a word is an omen, you call a sneeze an omen, a meeting an omen, an unknown sound an omen, a slave or an ass an omen. Is it not clear that we are a prophetic Apollo to you?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.stage: More and more rapidly from here on.
sp.p: If you recognize us as gods, we shall be your divining Muses, through us you will know the winds and the seasons, summer,winter, and the temperate months. We shall not withdraw ourselves to the highest clouds like Zeus, but shall be among you and shall give to youand to your children and the children of your children, health and wealth, long life, peace, youth, laughter, songs and feasts; in short, you will all be so well off,that you will be weary and cloyed with enjoyment.

sp.speaker: First Semi-Chorus
sp.p: Oh, rustic Muse of such varied note, tiotiotiotiotiotinx, I sing with you in the groves and on the mountain tops, tiotiotiotinx. I poured forth sacred strains from my golden throat in honor of the god Pan, tiotiotiotinx, from the top of the thickly leaved ash, and my voice mingles with the mighty choirs who extol Cybele on the mountain tops, totototototototototinx. 'Tis to our concerts that Phrynichus comes to pillage like a bee the ambrosia of his songs, the sweetness of which so charms the ear, tiotiotiotinx.

sp.speaker: Leader of First Semi-Chorus
sp.p: If there is one of you spectators who wishes to spend the rest of his life quietly among the birds, let him come to us. All that is disgraceful and forbidden by law on earth is on the contrary honorable among us, the birds. For instance, among you it's a crime to beat your father, but with us it's an estimable deed; it's considered fine to run straight at your father and hit him, saying, “Come, lift your spur if you want to fight.” The runaway slave, whom you brand, is only a spotted francolin with us. Are you Phrygian like Spintharus? Among us you would be the Phrygian bird, the goldfinch, of the race of Philemon. Are you a slave and a Carian like Execestides?Among us you can create yourself forefathers; you can always find relations. Does the son of Pisias want to betray the gates of the city to the foe? Let him become a partridge, the fitting offspring of his father; among us there is no shame in escaping as cleverly as a partridge.

sp.speaker: Second Semi-Chorus
sp.p: So the swans on the banks of the Hebrus, tiotiotiotiotiotinx, mingle their voices to serenade Apollo, tiotiotiotinx, flapping their wings the while, tiotiotiotinx; their notes reach beyond the clouds of heaven; they startle the various tribes of the beasts; a windless sky calms the waves, totototototototototinx; all Olympus resounds, and astonishment seizes its rulers; the Olympian graces and Muses cry aloud the strain, tiotiotiotinx.

sp.speaker: Leader of Second Semi-Chorus
sp.p: There is nothing more useful nor more pleasant than to have wings. To begin with, just let us suppose a spectator to be dying with hunger and to be weary of the choruses of the tragic poets; if he were winged, he would fly off, go home to dine and come back with his stomach filled.Some Patroclides, needing to take a crap, would not have to spill it out on his cloak, but could fly off, satisfy his requirements, let a few farts and, having recovered his breath, return. If one of you, it matters not who, had adulterous relations and saw the husband of his mistress in the seats of the senators, he might stretch his wings, fly to her, and, having laid her, resume his place. Is it not the most priceless gift of all, to be winged? Look at Diitrephes! His wings were only wicker-work ones, and yet he got himself chosen Phylarch and then Hipparch; from being nobody,he has risen to be famous; he's now the finest gilded cock of his tribe.

div1.stage: Pisthetaerus and Euelpides return; they now have wings.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Halloa! What's this? By Zeus! I never saw anything so funny in all my life.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: What makes you laugh?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Your little wings. D'you know what you look like? Like a goose painted by some dauber.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: And you look like a close-shaven blackbird.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: We ourselves asked for this transformation, and, as Aeschylus has it, “These are no borrowed feathers, but truly our own.”

sp.speaker: Epops
sp.p: Come now, what must be done?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: First give our city a great and famous name, then sacrifice to the gods.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: I think so too.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Let's see. What shall our city be called?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Will you have a high-sounding Laconian name? Shall we call it Sparta?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: What! call my town Sparta? Why, I would not use esparto for my bed, even though I had nothing but bands of rushes.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Well then, what name can you suggest?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Some name borrowed from the clouds, from these lofty regions in which we dwell —in short, some well-known name.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Do you like Nephelococcygia?

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Oh! capital! truly that's a brilliant thought!

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Is it in Nephelococcygia that all the wealth of Theogenes and most of Aeschines' is?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: No, it's rather the plain of Phlegra, where the gods withered the pride of the sons of the Earth with their shafts.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Oh! what a splendid city! But what god shall be its patron? for whom shall we weave the peplus?

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Why not choose Athena Polias?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Oh! what a well-ordered town it would be to have a female deity armed from head to foot, while Clisthenes was spinning!

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Who then shall guard the Pelargicon?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: A bird

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: One of us? What kind of bird?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: A bird of Persian strain, who is everywhere proclaimed to be the bravest of all, a true chick of Ares.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: Oh! noble chick!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Because he is a god well suited to live on the rocks. Come! into the air with you to help the workers who are building the wall; carry up rubble, strip yourself to mix the mortar, take up the hod, tumble down the ladder, if you like, post sentinels, keep the fire smouldering beneath the ashes, go round the walls, bell in hand, and go to sleep up there yourself; then despatch two heralds, one to the gods above, the other to mankind on earth and come back here.

sp.speaker: Euelpides
sp.p: As for yourself, remain here, and may the plague take you for a troublesome fellow!He departs.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Go, friend, go where I send you, for without you my orders cannot be obeyed. For myself, I want to sacrifice to the new god, and I am going to summon the priest who must preside at the ceremony.Slaves! slaves! bring forward the basket and the lustral water.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: I do as you do, and I wish as you wish, and I implore you to address powerful and solemn prayers to the gods, and in addition to immolate a sheep as a token of our gratitude. Let us sing the Pythian chant in honor of the god, and let Chaeris accompany our voices.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Enough! but, by Heracles! what is this? Great gods! I have seen many prodigious things, but I never saw a muzzled raven.The Priest arrives.Priest! it's high time! Sacrifice to the new gods.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: I begin, but where is the man with the basket? Pray to the Hestia of the birds, to the kite, who presides over the hearth, and to all the god and goddess-birds who dwell in Olympus . . .

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Oh! Hawk, the sacred guardian of Sunium, oh, god of the storks!

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: . . . to the swan of Delos, to Leto the mother of the quails, and to Artemis, the goldfinch . . .

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: It's no longer Artemis Colaenis, but Artemis the goldfinch.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: . . . to Bacchus, the finch and Cybele, the ostrich and mother of the godsand mankind. . .

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Oh! sovereign ostrich Cybele, mother of Cleocritus!

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: . . . to grant health and safety to the Nephelococcygians as well as to the dwellers in Chios . . .

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: The dwellers in Chios! Ah! I am delighted they should be thus mentioned on all occasions.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: . . . to the heroes, the birds, to the sons of heroes, to the porphyrion, the pelican, the spoon-bill, the redbreast, the grouse, the peacock, the horned-owl, the teal, the bittern, the heron, the stormy petrel, the fig-pecker, the titmouse . . .

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Stop! stop! you drive me crazy with your endless list. Why, wretch, to what sacred feast are you inviting the vultures and the sea-eagles? Don't you see that a single kite could easily carry off the lot at once? Begone, you and your fillets and all; I shall know how to complete the sacrifice by myself.

div1.stage: The Priest departs.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: It is imperative that I sing another sacred chant for the rite of the lustral water, and that I invoke the immortals, or at least one of them, provided always that you have some suitable food to offer him; from what I see here, in the shape of gifts, there is naught whatever but horn and hair.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Let us address our sacrifices and our prayers to the winged gods.

div1.stage: A Poet enters.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: Oh, Muse! celebrate happy Nephelococcygia in your hymns.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What have we here? Where did you come from, tell me? Who are you?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: I am he whose language is sweeter than honey, the zealous slave of the Muses, as Homer has it.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: You a slave! and yet you wear your hair long?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: No, but the fact is all we poets are the assiduous slaves of the Muses, according to Homer.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: In truth your little cloak is quite holy too through zeal! But, poet, what ill wind drove you here?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: I have composed verses in honor of your Nephelococcygia, a host of splendid dithyrambs and parthenia worthy of Simonides himself.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: And when did you compose them? How long since?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: Oh! 'tis long, aye, very long, that I have sung in honor of this city.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: But I am only celebrating its foundation with this sacrifice; I have only just named it, as is done with little babies.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: “Just as the chargers fly with the speed of the wind, so does the voice of the Muses take its flight. Oh! thou noble founder of the town of Aetna thou, whose name recalls the holy sacrifices, make us such gift as thy generous heart shall suggest.”He puts out his hand.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: He will drive us silly if we do not get rid of him by some present.To the Priest's acolyte. Here! you, who have a fur as well as your tunic, take it off and give it to this clever poet. Come, take this fur; you look to me to be shivering with cold.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: My Muse will gladly accept this gift; but engrave these verses of Pindar's on your mind.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Oh! what a pest! It's impossible then to get rid of him!

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: “Straton wanders among the Scythian nomads, but has no linen garment. He is sad at only wearing an animal's pelt and no tunic.” Do you get what I mean?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: I understand that you want me to offer you a tunic. Hi! you To the acolyte. take off yours; we must help the poet. . . . Come, you, take it and get out.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: I am going, and these are the verses that I address to this city: “Phoebus of the golden throne, celebrate this shivery, freezing city; I have travelled through fruitful and snow-covered plains. Tralala! Tralala!”He departs.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What are you chanting us about frosts? Thanks to the tunic, you no longer fear them. Ah! by Zeus! I could not have believed this cursed fellow could so soon have learnt the way to our city. To a slave. Come, take the lustral water and circle the altar. Let all keep silence!

div1.stage: An Oracle-Monger enters.

sp.speaker: Oracle-Monger
sp.p: Let not the goat be sacrificed.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Oracle-Monger
sp.p: Who am I? An oracle-monger.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Get out!

sp.speaker: Oracle-Monger
sp.p: Wretched man, insult not sacred things. For there is an oracle of Bacis, which exactly applies to Nephelococcygia.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Why did you not reveal it to me before I founded my city?

sp.speaker: Oracle-Monger
sp.p: The divine spirit was against it.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Well, I suppose there's nothing to do but hear the terms of the oracle.

sp.speaker: Oracle-Monger
sp.p: “But when the wolves and the white crows shall dwell together between Corinth and Sicyon ...”

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: But how do the Corinthians concern me?

sp.speaker: Oracle-Monger
sp.p: It is the regions of the air that Bacis indicates in this manner.
“They must first sacrifice a white-fleeced goat to Pandora, and give the prophet who first reveals my words a good cloak and new sandals.”

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Does it say sandals there?

sp.speaker: Oracle-Monger
sp.p: Look at the book.
“And besides this a goblet of wine and a good share of the entrails of the victim.”

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Of the entrails —does it say that?

sp.speaker: Oracle-Monger
sp.p: Look at the book.
“If you do as I command, divine youth, you shall be an eagle among the clouds; if not, you shall be neither turtle-dove, nor eagle, nor woodpecker.”

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Does it say all that?

sp.speaker: Oracle-Monger
sp.p: Look at the book.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: This oracle in no sort of way resembles the one Apollo dictated to me:
“If an impostor comes without invitation to annoy you during the sacrifice and to demand a share of the victim, apply a stout stick to his ribs.”

sp.speaker: Oracle-Monger
sp.p: You are drivelling.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Look at the book.
“And don't spare him, were he an eagle from out of the clouds, were it Lampon himself or the great Diopithes.”

sp.speaker: Oracle-Monger
sp.p: Does it say that?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Look at the book and go and hang yourself.

sp.speaker: Oracle-Monger
sp.p: Oh! unfortunate wretch that I am. He departs.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Away with you, and take your prophecies elsewhere.

div1.stage: Enter Meton, with surveying instruments.

sp.speaker: Meton
sp.p: I have come to you . . .

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Yet another pest! What have you come to do? What's your plan? What's the purpose of your journey? Why these splendid buskins?

sp.speaker: Meton
sp.p: I want to survey the plains of the air for you and to parcel them into lots.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: In the name of the gods, who are you?

sp.speaker: Meton
sp.p: Who am I? Meton, known throughout Greece and at Colonus.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What are these things?

sp.speaker: Meton
sp.p: Tools for measuring the air. In truth, the spaces in the air have precisely the form of a furnace. With this bent ruler I draw a line from top to bottom; from one of its points I describe a circle with the compass. Do you understand?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Not in the least.

sp.speaker: Meton
sp.p: With the straight ruler I set to work to inscribe a square within this circle; in its center will be the market-place, into which all the straight streets will lead, converging to this center like a star, which, although only orbicular, sends forth its rays in a straight line from all sides.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: A regular Thales! Meton . . .

sp.speaker: Meton
sp.p: What d'you want with me?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: I want to give you a proof of my friendship. Use your legs.

sp.speaker: Meton
sp.p: Why, what have I to fear?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: It's the same here as in Sparta. Strangers are driven away, and blows rain down as thick as hail.

sp.speaker: Meton
sp.p: Is there sedition in your city?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: No, certainly not.

sp.speaker: Meton
sp.p: What's wrong then?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: We are agreed to sweep all quacks and impostors far from our borders.

sp.speaker: Meton
sp.p: Then I'll be going.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: I'm afraid it's too late. The thunder growls already.

div1.stage: He beats him.

sp.speaker: Meton
sp.p: Oh, woe! oh, woe!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: I warned you. Now, be off, and do your surveying somewhere else.

div1.stage: Meton takes to his heels. He is no sooner gone than an Inspector arrives.

sp.speaker: Inspector
sp.p: Where are the Proxeni?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Who is this Sardanapalus?

sp.speaker: Inspector
sp.p: I have been appointed by lot to come to Nephelococcygia as inspector.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: An inspector! and who sends you here, you rascal?

sp.speaker: Inspector
sp.p: A decree of Teleas.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Will you just pocket your salary, do nothing, and get out?

sp.speaker: Inspector
sp.p: Indeed I will; I am urgently needed to be at Athens to attend the Assembly; for I am charged with the interests of Pharnaces.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Take it then, and get on your way. This is your salary. He beats him.

sp.speaker: Inspector
sp.p: What does this mean?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: This is the assembly where you have to defend Pharnaces.

sp.speaker: Inspector
sp.p: You shall testify that they dare to strike me, the inspector.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Are you not going to get out with your urns? It's not to be believed; they send us inspectors before we have so much as paid sacrifice to the gods. The Inspector goes into hiding. A Dealer in Decrees arrives.

sp.speaker: Dealer in Decrees
sp.p: “If the Nephelococcygian does wrong to the Athenian ...”

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What trouble now? What book is that?

sp.speaker: Dealer in Decrees
sp.p: I am a dealer in decrees, and I have come here to sell you the new laws.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Which?

sp.speaker: Dealer in Decrees
sp.p: “The Nephelococcygians shall adopt the same weights, measures and decrees as the Olophyxians.”

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: And you shall soon be imitating the Ototyxians.

div1.stage: He beats him.

sp.speaker: Dealer in Decrees
sp.p: Ow! what are you doing?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Now will you get out of here with your decrees? For I am going to let you see some severe ones.

div1.stage: The Dealer in Decrees departs; the Inspector comes out of hiding.

sp.speaker: Inspector
sp.p: I summon Pisthetaerus for outrage for the month of Munychion.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Ha! my friend! are you still here?

div1.stage: The Dealer in Decrees also returns.

sp.speaker: Dealer in Decrees
sp.p: “Should anyone drive away the magistrates and not receive them, according to the decree duly posted ...”

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What! rascal! you are back too?

div1.stage: He rushes at him.

sp.speaker: Inspector
sp.p: Woe to you! I'll have you condemned to a fine of ten thousand drachmae.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: And I'll smash your urns.

sp.speaker: Inspector
sp.p: Do you recall that evening when you crapped on the column where the decrees are posted?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Here! here! let him be seized.
Why, don't you want to stay any longer? But let us get indoors as quick as possible; we will sacrifice the goat inside.

sp.speaker: First Semi-Chorus
Leader of First Semi-Chorus
sp.p: I hear it proclaimed: “A talent for him who shall kill Diagoras of Melos, and a talent for him who destroys one of the dead tyrants.” We likewise wish to make our proclamation: “A talent to him among you who shall kill Philocrates, the Struthian; four, if he brings him to us alive. For this Philocrates skewers the finches together and sells them at the rate of an obolus for seven. He tortures the thrushes by blowing them out, so that they may look bigger, sticks their own feathers into the nostrils of blackbirds, and collects pigeons, which he shuts up and forces them, fastened in a net, to decoy others.” That is what we wish to proclaim. And if anyone is keeping birds shut up in his yard, let him hasten to let them loose; those who disobey shall be seized by the birds and we shall put them in chains, so that in their turn they may decoy other men.

sp.speaker: Second Semi-Chorus
Leader of Second Semi-Chorus
sp.p: I want now to speak to the judges about the prize they are going to award; if they are favourable to us, we will load them with benefits far greater than those Paris received. Firstly, the owls of Laurium, which every judge desires above all things, shall never be wanting to you; you shall see them homing with you, building their nests in your money-bags and laying coins. Besides, you shall be housed like the gods, for we shall erect gables over your dwellings; if you hold some public post and want to do a little pilfering, we will give you the sharp claws of a hawk. Are you dining in town, we will provide you with stomachs as capacious as a bird's crop. But, if your award is against us, don't fail to have metal covers fashioned for yourselves, like those they place over statues; else, look out! for the day you wear a white tunic all the birds will soil it with their droppings.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Birds! the sacrifice is propitious. But I see no messenger coming from the wall to tell us what is happening. Ah! here comes one running himself out of breath as though he were in the Olympic stadium.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Where, where, where is he? Where, where, where is he? Where, where, where is he? Where is Pisthetaerus, our leader?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Here am I.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: The wall is finished.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: That's good news.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: It's a most beautiful, a most magnificent work of art. The wall is so broad that Proxenides, the Braggartian, and Theogenes could pass each other in their chariots, even if they were drawn by steeds as big as the Trojan horse.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: That's fine!

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Its length is one hundred stadia; I measured it myself.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: A decent length, by Poseidon! And who built such a wall?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Birds —birds only; they had neither Egyptian brickmaker, nor stonemason, nor carpenter; the birds did it all themselves; I could hardly believe my eyes. Thirty thousand cranes came from Libya with a supply of stones, intended for the foundations. The water-rails chiselled them with their beaks. Ten thousand storks were busy making bricks; plovers and other water fowl carried water into the air.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: And who carried the mortar?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Herons, in hods.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: But how could they put the mortar into the hods?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Oh! it was a truly clever invention; the geese used their feet like spades; they buried them in the pile of mortar and then emptied them into the hods.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Ah! to what use cannot feet be put?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: You should have seen how eagerly the ducks carried bricks. To complete the tale, the swallows came flying to the work, their beaks full of mortar and their trowels on their backs, just the way little children are carried.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Who would want paid servants after this? But tell me, who did the woodwork?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Birds again, and clever carpenters too, the pelicans, for they squared up the gates with their beaks in such a fashion that one would have thought they were using axes; the noise was just like a dockyard. Now the whole wall is tight everywhere, securely bolted and well guarded; it is patrolled, bell in hand; the sentinels stand everywhere and beacons burn on the towers. But I must run off to clean myself; the rest is your business.

div1.stage: He departs.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Well! what do you say to it? Are you not astonished at the wall being completed so quickly?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: By the gods, yes, and with good reason. It's really not to be believed. But here comes another messenger from the wall to bring us some further news! What a fighting look he has!

sp.speaker: Second Messenger
sp.p: Alas! alas! alas! alas! alas! alas!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Second Messenger
sp.p: A horrible outrage has occurred; a god sent by Zeus has passed through our gates and has penetrated the realms of the air without the knowledge of the jays, who are on guard in the daytime.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: It's a terrible and criminal deed. What god was it?

sp.speaker: Second Messenger
sp.p: We don't know that. All we know is, that he has got wings.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Why were not patrolmen sent against him at once?

sp.speaker: Second Messenger
sp.p: We have despatched thirty thousand hawks of the legion of Mounted Archers. All the hook-clawed birds are moving against him, the kestrel, the buzzard, the vulture, the great-horned owl; they cleave the air so that it resounds with the flapping of their wings; they are looking everywhere for the god, who cannot be far away; indeed, if I mistake not, he is coming from yonder side.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: To arms, all, with slings and bows! This way, all our soldiers; shoot and strike! Some one give me a sling!

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: War, a terrible war is breaking out between us and the gods! Come, let each one guard Air, the son of Erebus, in which the clouds float. Take care no immortal enters it without your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Leader of the Chorus
sp.p: Scan all sides with your glance. Hark! methinks I can hear the rustle of the swift wings of a god from heaven.

div1.stage: The Machine brings in Iris, in the form of a young girl.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Hi! you woman! where, where, where are you flying to? Halt, don't stir! keep motionless! not a beat of your wing! She pauses in her flight. Who are you and from what country? You must say whence you come.

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: I come from the abode of the Olympian gods.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What's your name, ship or head-dress?

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: I am swift Iris.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Paralus or Salaminia?

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Let a buzzard rush at her and seize her.

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: Seize me? But what do all these insults mean?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Woe to you!

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: I do not understand it.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: By which gate did you pass through the wall, wretched woman?

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: By which gate? Why, great gods, I don't know.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: You hear how she holds us in derision. Did you present yourself to the officers in command of the jays? You don't answer. Have you a permit, bearing the seal of the storks?

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: Am I dreaming?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Did you get one?

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: Are you mad?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: No head-bird gave you a safe-conduct?

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: A safe-conduct to me. You poor fool!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Ah! and so you slipped into this city on the sly and into these realms of air-land that don't belong to you.

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: And what other roads can the gods travel?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: By Zeus! I know nothing about that, not I. But they won't pass this way. And you still dare to complain? Why, if you were treated according to your deserts, no Iris would ever have more justly suffered death.

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: I am immortal.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: You would have died nevertheless. —Oh! that would be truly intolerable! What! should the universe obey us and the gods alone continue their insolence and not understand that they must submit to the law of the strongest in their due turn? But tell me, where are you flying to?

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: I? The messenger of Zeus to mankind, I am going to tell them to sacrifice sheep and oxen on the altars and to fill their streets with the rich smoke of burning fat.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Of which gods are you speaking?

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: Of which? Why, of ourselves, the gods of heaven.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: You, gods?

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: Are there others then?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Men now adore the birds as gods, and it's to them, by Zeus, that they must offer sacrifices, and not to Zeus at all!

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: Oh! fool! fool! Rouse not the wrath of the gods, for it is terrible indeed. Armed with the brand of Zeus, Justice would annihilate your race; the lightning would strike you as it did Licymnius and consume both your body and the porticos of your palace.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Here! that's enough tall talk. Just you listen and keep quiet! Do you take me for a Lydian or a Phrygian and think to frighten me with your big words? Know, that if Zeus worries me again, I shall go at the head of my eagles, who are armed with lightning, and reduce his dwelling and that of Amphion to cinders. I shall send more than six hundred porphyrions clothed in leopards' skins up to heaven against him; and formerly a single Porphyrion gave him enough to do. As for you, his messenger, if you annoy me, I shall begin by getting between your thighs, and even though you are Iris, you will be surprised at the erection the old man can produce; it's three times as good as the ram on a ship's prow!

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: May you perish, you wretch, you and your infamous words!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Won't you get out of here quickly? Come, stretch your wings or look out for squalls!

sp.speaker: Iris
sp.p: If my father does not punish you for your insults ...

div1.stage: The Machine takes Iris away.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Ha! ... but just you be off elsewhere to roast younger folk than us with your lightning.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: We forbid the gods, the sons of Zeus, to pass through our city and the mortals to send them the smoke of their sacrifices by this road.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: It's odd that the messenger we sent to the mortals has never returned.

div1.stage: The Herald enters, wearing a golden garland on his head.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: Oh! blessed Pisthetaerus, very wise, very illustrious, very gracious, thrice happy, very ... Come, prompt me, somebody, do

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Get to your story!

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: All peoples are filled with admiration for your wisdom, and they award you this golden crown.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: I accept it. But tell me, why do the people admire me?

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: Oh you, who have founded so illustrious a city in the air, you know not in what esteem men hold you and how many there are who burn with desire to dwell in it. Before your city was built, all men had a mania for Sparta; long hair and fasting were held in honor, men went dirty like Socrates and carried staves. Now all is changed. Firstly, as soon as it's dawn, they all spring out of bed together to go and seek their food, the same as you do; then they fly off towards the notices and finally devour the decrees. The bird-madness is so clear that many actually bear the names of birds. There is a halting victualler, who styles himself the partridge; Menippus calls himself the swallow; Opuntius the one-eyed crow; Philocles the lark; Theogenes the fox-goose; Lycurgus the ibis; Chaerephon the bat; Syracosius the magpie; Midias the quail; indeed he looks like a quail that has been hit hard on the head. Out of love for the birds they repeat all the songs which concern the swallow, the teal, the goose or the pigeon; in each verse you see wings, or at all events a few feathers. This is what is happening down there. Finally, there are more than ten thousand folk who are coming here from earth to ask you for feathers and hooked claws; so, mind you supply yourself with wings for the immigrants.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Ah! by Zeus, there's no time for idling. To some slaves. Go as quick as possible and fill every hamper, every basket you can find with wings. Manes will bring them to me outside the walls, where I will welcome those who present themselves.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: This town will soon be inhabited by a crowd of men. Fortune favours us alone and thus they have fallen in love with our city.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.stage: To the slave Manes, who brings in a basket full of wings.
sp.p: Come, hurry up and bring them along.

sp.speaker: Chorus
