sp.p: Will not man find here everything that can please him —wisdom, love, the divine Graces, the sweet face of gentle peace?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.stage: As Manes comes in with another basket.
sp.p: Oh! you lazy servant! won't you hurry yourself?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Let a basket of wings be brought speedily. Come, beat him as I do, and put some life into him; he is as lazy as an ass.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Aye, Manes is a great craven.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Begin by putting this heap of wings in order; divide them in three parts according to the birds from whom they came; the singing, the prophetic and the aquatic birds; then you must take care to distribute them to the men according to their character.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.stage: To Manes, who is bringing in another basket.
sp.p: Oh! by the kestrels! I can keep my hands off you no longer; you are too slow and lazy altogether.

div1.stage: He hits Manes, who runs away. A young Parricide enters.

sp.speaker: Parricide
sp.p: Oh! might I but become an eagle, who soars in the skies! Oh! might I fly abovethe azure waves of the barren sea!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Ha! it would seem the news was true; I hear someone coming who talks of wings.

sp.speaker: Parricide
sp.p: Nothing is more charming than to fly; I am bird-mad and fly towards you, for I want to live with you and to obey your laws.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Which laws? The birds have many laws.

sp.speaker: Parricide
sp.p: All of them; but the one that pleases me most is that among the birds it is considered a fine thing to peck and strangle one's father.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Yes, by Zeus! according to us, he who dares to strike his father, while still a chick, is a brave fellow.

sp.speaker: Parricide
sp.p: And therefore I want to dwell here, for I want to strangle my father and inherit his wealth.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: But we have also an ancient law written in the code of the storks, which runs thus, “When the stork father has reared his young and has taught them to fly, the young must in their turn support the father.”

sp.speaker: Parricide
sp.p: It's hardly worth while coming all this distance to be compelled to keep my father!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: No, no, young friend, since you have come to us with such willingness, I am going to give you these black wings, as though you were an orphan bird; furthermore, some good advice, that I received myself in infancy. Don't strike your father, but take these wings in one hand and these spurs in the other; imagine you have a cock's crest on your head and go and mount guard and fight; live on your pay and respect your father's life. You're a gallant fellow! Very well, then! Fly to Thrace and fight.

sp.speaker: Parricide
sp.p: By Bacchus! You're right; I will follow your counsel.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: It's acting wisely, by Zeus..

div1.stage: The Parricide departs, and the dithyrambic poet Cinesias arrives.

sp.speaker: Cinesias
sp.p: “On my light pinions I soar off to Olympus; in its capricious flight my Muse flutters along the thousand paths of poetry in turn ...”

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: This is a fellow will need a whole shipload of wings.

sp.speaker: Cinesias
sp.p: “... and being fearless and vigorous, it is seeking fresh outlet.”

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Welcome, Cinesias, you lime-wood man! Why have you come here twisting your game leg in circles?

sp.speaker: Cinesias
sp.p: “I want to become a bird, a tuneful nightingale.”

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Enough of that sort of ditty. Tell me what you want.

sp.speaker: Cinesias
sp.p: Give me wings and I will fly into the topmost airs to gather fresh songs in the clouds, in the midst of the vapors and the fleecy snow.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Gather songs in the clouds?

sp.speaker: Cinesias
sp.p: 'Tis on them the whole of our latter-day art depends. The most brilliant dithyrambs are those that flap their wings in empty space and are clothed in mist and dense obscurity. To appreciate this, just listen.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Oh! no, no, no!

sp.speaker: Cinesias
sp.p: By Hermes! but indeed you shall.
“I shall travel through thine ethereal empire like a winged bird, who cleaveth space with his long neck ...”

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Stop! Way enough!

sp.speaker: Cinesias
sp.p: “... as I soar over the seas, carried by the breath of the winds ...”

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: By Zeus! I'll cut your breath short. He picks up a pair of wings and begins trying to stop Cinesias' mouth with them.

sp.speaker: Cinesias
sp.p: “... now rushing along the tracks of Notus, now nearing Boreasacross the infinite wastes of the ether.”
Ah! old man, that's a pretty and clever idea truly!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What! are you not delighted to be cleaving the air?

sp.speaker: Cinesias
sp.p: To treat a dithyrambic poet, for whom the tribes dispute with each other, in this style!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Will you stay with us and form a chorus of winged birds as slender as Leotrophides for the Cecropid tribe?

sp.speaker: Cinesias
sp.p: You are making game of me, that's clear; but know that I shall never leave you in peace if I do not have wings wherewith to traverse the air.

div1.stage: Cinesias departs and an Informer arrives.

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: What are these birds with downy feathers, who look so pitiable to me? Tell me, oh swallow with the long dappled wings.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Oh! it's a regular invasion that threatens us. Here comes another one, humming along.

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: Swallow with the long dappled wings, once more I summon you.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: It's his cloak I believe he's addressing; it stands in great need of the swallows' return.

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: Where is he who gives out wings to all comers?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Here I am, but you must tell me for what purpose you want them.

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: Ask no questions. I want wings, and wings I must have.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Do you want to fly straight to Pellene?

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: I? Why, I am an accuser of the islands, an informer ...

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: A fine trade, truly!

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: ... a hatcher of lawsuits. Hence I have great need of wings to prowl round the cities and drag them before justice.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Would you do this better if you had wings?

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: No, but I should no longer fear the pirates; I should return with the cranes, loaded with a supply of lawsuits by way of ballast.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: So it seems, despite all your youthful vigor, you make it your trade to denounce strangers?

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: Well, and why not? I don't know how to dig.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: But, by Zeus! there are honest ways of gaining a living at your age without all this infamous trickery.

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: My friend, I am asking you for wings, not for words.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: It's just my words that gives you wings.

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: And how can you give a man wings with your words?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: They all start this way.

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Have you not often heard the father say to young men in the barbers' shops, “It's astonishing how Diitrephes' advice has made my son fly to horse-riding.” —“Mine,” says another, “has flown towards tragic poetry on the wings of his imagination.”

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: So that words give wings?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Undoubtedly; words give wings to the mind and make a man soar to heaven. Thus I hope that my wise words will give you wings to fly to some less degrading trade.

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: But I do not want to.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What do you reckon on doing then?

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: I won't belie my breeding; from generation to generation we have lived by informing. Quick, therefore, give me quickly some light, swift hawk or kestrel wings, so that I may summon the islanders, sustain the accusation here, and haste back there again on flying pinions.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: I see. In this way the stranger will be condemned even before he appears.

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: That's just it.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: And while he is on his way here by sea, you will be flying to the islands to despoil him of his property.

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: You've hit it, precisely; I must whirl hither and thither like a perfect humming-top.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: I catch the idea. Wait, I've got some fine Corcyraean wings. How do you like them?

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: Oh! woe is me! Why, it's a whip!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: No, no; these are the wings, I tell you, that make the top spin.

sp.speaker: Informer
sp.p: Oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Take your flight, clear off, you miserable cur, or you will soon see what comes of quibbling and lying. The Informer flees. To his slaves. Come, let us gather up our wings and withdraw.The baskets are taken away.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: In my ethereal flights I have seen many things new and strange and wondrous beyond belief. There is a tree called Cleonymus belonging to an unknown species; it has no heart, is good for nothing and is as tall as it is cowardly. In springtime it shoots forth calumnies instead of buds and in autumn it strews the ground with bucklers in place of leaves.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Far away in the regions of darkness, where no ray of light ever enters, there is a country, where men sit at the table of the heroes and dwell with them always —except in the evening.Should any mortal meet the hero Orestes at night, he would soon be stripped and covered with blows from head to foot.

sp.stage: Prometheus enters, masked to conceal his identify.

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: Ah! by the gods! if only Zeus does not see me! Where is Pisthetaerus?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Ha! what is this? A masked man!

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: Can you see any god behind me?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: No, none. But who are you, pray?

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: What's the time, please?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: The time? Why, it's past noon. Who are you?

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: Is it the fall of day? Is it no later than that?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: This is getting dull!

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: What is Zeus doing? Is he dispersing the clouds or gathering them?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Watch out for yourself!

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: Come, I will raise my mask.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Ah! my dear Prometheus!

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: Sh! Sh! speak lower!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, Prometheus?

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: Sh! sh! Don't call me by my name; you will be my ruin, if Zeus should see me here. But, if you want me to tell you how things are going in heaven, take this umbrella and shield me, so that the gods don't see me.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: I can recognize Prometheus in this cunning trick. Come, quick then, and fear nothing; speak on.

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: Then listen.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: I am listening, proceed!

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: Zeus is done for.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Ah! and since when, pray?

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: Since you founded this city in the air. There is not a man who now sacrifices to the gods; the smoke of the victims no longer reaches us. Not the smallest offering comes! We fast as though it were the festival of Demeter. The barbarian gods, who are dying of hunger, are bawling like Illyrians and threaten to make an armed descent upon Zeus, if he does not open markets where joints of the victims are sold.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What! there are other gods besides you, barbarian gods who dwell above Olympus?

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: If there were no barbarian gods, who would be the patron of Execestides?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: And what is the name of these gods?

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: Their name? Why, the Triballi.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Ah, indeed! 'tis from that no doubt that we derive the word ‘tribulation.'

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: Most likely. But one thing I can tell you for certain, namely, that Zeus and the celestial Triballi are going to send deputies here to sue for peace. Now don't you treat with them, unless Zeus restores the scepter to the birds and gives you Basileia in marriage.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Who is this Basileia?

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: A very fine young damsel, who makes the lightning for Zeus; all things come from her, wisdom, good laws, virtue, the fleet, calumnies, the public paymaster and the triobolus.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Ah! then she is a sort of general manageress to the god.

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: Yes, precisely. If he gives you her for your wife, yours will be the almighty power. That is what I have come to tell you; for you know my constant and habitual goodwill towards men.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Oh, yes! it's thanks to you that we roast our meat.

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: I hate the gods, as you know.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Aye, by Zeus, you have always detested them.

sp.speaker: Prometheus
sp.p: Towards them I am a veritable Timon; but I must return in all haste, so give me the umbrella; if Zeus should see me from up there, he would think I was escorting one of the Canephori.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Wait, take this stool as well. Prometheus leaves. Pisthetaerus goes into the thicket.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Near by the land of the Sciapodes there is a marsh, from the borders whereof the unwashed Socrates evokes the souls of men. Pisander came one day to see his soul, which he had left there when still alive. He offered a little victim, a camel, slit his throat and, following the example of Odysseus, stepped one pace backwards. Then that bat of a Chaerephon came up from hell to drink the camel's blood.

div1.stage: Poseidon enters, accompanied by Heracles and Triballus.

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: This is the city of Nephelococcygia, to which we come as ambassadors.

Hi! what are you up to? you are throwing your cloak over the left shoulder. Come, fling it quick over the right! And why, pray, does it draggle in this fashion? Have you ulcers to hide like Lespodias? Oh! democracy! whither, oh! whither are you leading us? Is it possible that the gods have chosen such an envoy? You are undisturbed? Ugh! you cursed savage! you are by far the most barbarous of all the gods. —Tell me, Heracles, what are we going to do?

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: I have already told you that I want to strangle the fellow who dared to wall us out.

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: But, my friend, we are envoys of peace.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: All the more reason why I wish to strangle him.

div1.stage: Pisthetaerus comes out of the thicket, followed by slaves, who are carrying various kitchen utensils; one of them sets up a table on which he places poultry dressed for roasting.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Hand me the cheese-grater; bring me the silphium for sauce; pass me the cheese and watch the coals.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: Mortal! we who greet you are three gods.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Wait a bit till I have prepared my silphium pickle.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: What are these meats?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: These are birds that have been punished with death for attacking the people's friends.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: And you are going to season them before answering us?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.stage: Looking up from his work for the first time.
sp.p: Ah! Heracles! welcome, welcome! What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: The gods have sent us here as ambassadors to treat for peace.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: There's no more oil in the flask.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: And yet the birds must be thoroughly basted with it.

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: We have no interest to serve in fighting you; as for you, be friends and we promise that you shall always have rain-water in your pools and the warmest of warm weather. So far as these points go we are plenipotentiaries.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: We have never been the aggressors, and even now we are as well disposed for peace as yourselves, provided you agree to one equitable condition, namely, that Zeus yield his scepter to the birds. If only this is agreed to, I invite the ambassadors to dinner.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: That's good enough for me. I vote for peace.

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: You wretch! you are nothing but a fool and a glutton. Do you want to dethrone your own father?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: What an error. Why, the gods will be much more powerful if the birds govern the earth. At present the mortals are hidden beneath the clouds, escape your observation, and commit perjury in your name; but if you had the birds for your allies, and a man, after having sworn by the crow and Zeus, should fail to keep his oath, the crow would dive down upon him unawares and pluck out his eye.

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: Well thought of, by Poseidon!

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: My notion too.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: And you, what's your opinion?

sp.speaker: Triballus
sp.p: Nabasatreu.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: D'you see? he also approves. But listen, here is another thing in which we can serve you. If a man vows to offer a sacrifice to some god, and then procrastinates, pretending that the gods can wait, and thus does not keep his word, we shall punish his stinginess.

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: Ah! and how?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: While he is counting his money or is in the bath, a kite will relieve him, before he knows it, either in coin or in clothes, of the value of a couple of sheep, and carry it to the god.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: I vote for restoring them the scepter.

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: Ask Triballus.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: Hi! Triballus, do you want a thrashing?

sp.speaker: Triballus
sp.p: Sure, bashum head withum stick.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: He says, “Right willingly.”

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: If that be the opinion of both of you, why, I consent too.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: Very well! we accord you the scepter.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Ah! I was nearly forgetting another condition. I will leave Here to Zeus, but only if the young Basileia is given me in marriage.

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: Then you don't want peace. Let us withdraw.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: It matters mighty little to me. Cook, look to the gravy.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: What an odd fellow this Poseidon is! Where are you off to? Are we going to war about a woman?

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: What else is there to do?

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: What else? Why, conclude peace.

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: Oh! you blockhead! do you always want to be fooled? Why, you are seeking your own downfall. If Zeus were to die, after having yielded them the sovereignty, you would be ruined, for you are the heir of all the wealth he will leave behind.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Oh! by the gods! how he is cajoling you. Step aside, that I may have a word with you. Your uncle is getting the better of you, my poor friend. The law will not allow you an obolus of the paternal property, for you are a bastard and not a legitimate child.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: I a bastard! What's that you tell me?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Why, certainly; are you not born of a stranger woman? Besides, is not Athena recognized as Zeus' sole heiress? And no daughter would be that, if she had a legitimate brother.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: But what if my father wished to give me his property on his death-bed, even though I be a bastard?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: The law forbids it, and this same Poseidon would be the first to lay claim to his wealth, in virtue of being his legitimate brother. Listen; thus runs Solon's law: “A bastard shall not inherit, if there are legitimate children; and if there are no legitimate children, the property shall pass to the nearest kin.”

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: And I get nothing whatever of the paternal property?

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Absolutely nothing. But tell me, has your father had you entered on the registers of his phratry?

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: No, and I have long been surprised at the omission.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Why do you shake your fist at heaven? Do you want to fight? Why, be on my side, I will make you a king and will feed you on bird's milk and honey.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: Your further condition seems fair to me. I cede you the young damsel.

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: But I, I vote against this opinion.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Then it all depends on the Triballus. To the Triballus. What do you say?

sp.speaker: Triballus
sp.p: Givum bird pretty gel bigum queen.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: He says give her.

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: Why no, he does not say anything of the sort, or else, like the swallows he does not know how to walk.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Exactly so. Does he not say she must be given to the swallows?

sp.speaker: Poseidon
sp.p: All right, you two arrange the matter; make peace, since you wish it so; I'll hold my tongue.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: We are of a mind to grant you all that you ask. But come up there with us to receive Basileia and the celestial bounty.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Here are birds already dressed, and very suitable for a nuptial feast.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: You go and, if you like, I will stay here to roast them.

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: You to roast them? you are too much the glutton; come along with us.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: Ah! how well I would have treated myself!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Let some one bring me a beautiful and magnificent tunic for the wedding.The tunic is brought. Pisthetaerus and the three gods depart.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: At Phanae, near the Clepsydra, there dwells a people who have neither faith nor law, the Englottogastors, who reap, sow, pluck the vines and the figs with their tongues; they belong to a barbaric race, and among them the Philippi and the Gorgiases are to be found; 'tis these Englottogastorian Philippi who introduced the custom all over Attica of cutting out the tongue separately at sacrifices.

div1.stage: A Messenger enters.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Oh, you, whose unbounded happiness I cannot express in words, thrice happy race of airy birds, receive your king in your fortunate dwellings. More brilliant than the brightest star that illumes the earth, he is approaching his glittering golden palace; the sun itself does not shine with more dazzling glory. He is entering with his bride at his side, whose beauty no human tongue can express; in his hand he brandishes the lightning, the winged shaft of Zeus; perfumes of unspeakable sweetness pervade the ethereal realms. 'Tis a glorious spectacle to see the clouds of incense wafting in light whirlwinds before the breath of the zephyr! But here he is himself. Divine Muse! let thy sacred lips begin with songs of happy omen.

div1.stage: Pisthetaerus enters, with a crown on his head; he is accompanied by Basileia.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Fall back! to the right! to the left! advance! Fly around this happy mortal, whom Fortune loads with her blessings. Oh! oh! what grace! what beauty!

Oh, marriage so auspicious for our city! All honor to this man! 'tis through him that the birds are called to such glorious destinies. Let your nuptial hymns, your nuptial songs, greethim and his Basileia!

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: 'Twas in the midst of such festivities that the Fates formerly united Olympian Hera to the King who governs the gods from the summit of his inaccessible throne. Oh! Hymen! oh! Hymenaeus!

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Rosy Eros with the golden wings held the reins and guided the chariot; 'twas he, who presided over the union of Zeus and the fortunate Hera. Oh! Hymen! oh! Hymenaeus!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: I am delighted with your songs, I applaud your verses. Now celebratethe thunder that shakes the earth, the flaming lightning of Zeus and the terrible flashing thunderbolt.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Oh, thou golden flash of the lightning! oh, ye divine shafts of flame, that Zeus has hitherto shot forth! Oh, ye rolling thunders, that bring down the rain! 'Tis by the order of our king that ye shall now stagger the earth! Oh, Hymen! 'tis through thee that he commands the universe and that he makes Basileia, whom he has robbed from Zeus, take her seat at his side. Oh! Hymen! oh! Hymenaeus!

sp.speaker: Pisthetaerus
sp.p: Let all the winged tribes of our fellow-citizens follow the bridal couple to the palace of Zeus and to the nuptial couch! Stretch forth your hands, my dear wife! Take hold of me by my wings and let us dance; I am going to lift you up and carry you through the air.

div1.stage: Pisthetaerus and Basileia leave dancing; the Chorus follows them.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Alalalai ie Paian! Tenella kallinikos! Loftiest art thou of gods!
